articles.headline: An Ancient River in Syria Sections Off a Modern War
articles.snippet: A trip along the Euphrates reveals damaged and depopulated towns, and an uneasy front held by a tenuous American presence.
articles.abstract: A trip along the Euphrates reveals damaged and depopulated towns, and an uneasy front held by a tenuous American presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZOUR MAGHAR, Syria — On the eastern bank of the Euphrates River, Kurdish militiamen aligned with American troops burrow into sandbagged positions and eye their foes across the water.

articles.headline: United States and Mexico Are Nearing Nafta Compromise
articles.snippet: The United States and Mexico made progress toward a Nafta agreement during two days of talks in Washington this week, but Canada still needs to be brought to the table.
articles.abstract: The United States and Mexico made progress toward a Nafta agreement during two days of talks in Washington this week, but Canada still needs to be brought to the table.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Mexico are edging closer to agreement on how to rewrite key portions of the North American Free Trade Agreement, with the two countries making progress on rules related to automobiles and other remaining issues during two days of meetings that ended on Friday in Washington.

articles.headline: Paul Manafort Was Deep in Debt. He Saw an Opportunity in Trump.
articles.snippet: Prosecutors in Mr. Manafort’s bank and tax fraud trial say he was desperate for money. Why, then, did he volunteer to work unpaid in a top post in the Trump campaign?
articles.abstract: Prosecutors in Mr. Manafort’s bank and tax fraud trial say he was desperate for money. Why, then, did he volunteer to work unpaid in a top post in the Trump campaign?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul Manafort’s services did not come cheap. His consulting work helped prop up foreign strongmen, who in turn kept him in $12,000 bespoke suits from Beverly Hills.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Eileen Sullivan and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: There’s Trump’s Foreign Policy and Then There’s His Administration’s
articles.snippet: Nowhere were these differences more jarring than in the response to concerns that the Russian government is plotting to interfere in the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Nowhere were these differences more jarring than in the response to concerns that the Russian government is plotting to interfere in the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the last five days, President Trump has thanked Kim Jong-un of North Korea for his “nice letter,” reminisced about his “great meeting” with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and offered to meet Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, without any preconditions.

articles.headline: South Africa Vows to End Corruption. Are Its New Leaders Part of the Problem?
articles.snippet: The spectacular climb of David Mabuza, the country’s new deputy president, included siphoning off money from schools and other public services to amass enormous power, officials say.
articles.abstract: The spectacular climb of David Mabuza, the country’s new deputy president, included siphoning off money from schools and other public services to amass enormous power, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDDELPLAAS, South Africa — The little girl hated going to the bathroom at school. The pit toilets were so dark, dirty and crumbling. Many children were so afraid of them that they simply relieved themselves in the schoolyard to avoid the ordeal.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Selam Gebrekidan

articles.headline: The Partisan Battle Brett Kavanaugh Now Regrets
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court nominee, despite his own doubts, left his Washington law firm to rejoin the investigation into President Bill Clinton’s affair with Monica Lewinsky.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court nominee, despite his own doubts, left his Washington law firm to rejoin the investigation into President Bill Clinton’s affair with Monica Lewinsky.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the beginning of 1998, Brett M. Kavanaugh seemed set: a Yale law degree, three judicial clerkships, including one with Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, and, less than a decade out of law school, a coveted partnership at Kirkland & Ellis, a prominent law firm with offices a block from the White House.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Beyond the N.R.A.: Maria Butina’s Peculiar Bid for Russian Influence
articles.snippet: A Rockefeller heir, an Eisenhower, an array of Republican lawmakers — the accused Russian agent sought powerful connections outside the gun-rights group.
articles.abstract: A Rockefeller heir, an Eisenhower, an array of Republican lawmakers — the accused Russian agent sought powerful connections outside the gun-rights group.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Twelve days after a young Russian gun-rights activist gained access to some of America’s most prominent conservatives, at an elegant dinner near the Capitol, a Republican operative was eager to keep the momentum going.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Mike McIntire, Michael LaForgia, Andrew E. Kramer and Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: He’s a Superstar Pastor. She Worked for Him and Says He Groped Her Repeatedly.
articles.snippet: Bill Hybels built an iconic evangelical church outside Chicago. A former assistant says that in the 1980s, he sexually harassed her.
articles.abstract: Bill Hybels built an iconic evangelical church outside Chicago. A former assistant says that in the 1980s, he sexually harassed her.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOUTH BARRINGTON, Ill. — After the pain of watching her marriage fall apart, Pat Baranowski felt that God was suddenly showering her with blessings.

articles.headline: White Nationalists Love Corey Stewart. He Keeps Them Close.
articles.snippet: The Republican nominee for Senate in Virginia likes to engage the racial fringes of his party, creating a dilemma for mainstream G.O.P. leaders wary of his views.
articles.abstract: The Republican nominee for Senate in Virginia likes to engage the racial fringes of his party, creating a dilemma for mainstream G.O.P. leaders wary of his views.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODBRIDGE, Va. — Corey Stewart stands at the end of a long driveway that leads back in time, to his 18th century plantation manor hidden in woods behind a modern housing development. Mr. Stewart, the Republican Senate nominee from Virginia, treats the brick home like a living museum, complete with buttons from Redcoats, a Civil War soldier’s belt buckle and a room dedicated to George and Martha Washington, who were once visitors.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: President Admits Trump Tower Meeting Was Meant to Get Dirt on Clinton
articles.snippet: President Trump claimed that the June 2016 meeting was “totally legal,” though it is a key subject of the investigation by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.
articles.abstract: President Trump claimed that the June 2016 meeting was “totally legal,” though it is a key subject of the investigation by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Sunday that a Trump Tower meeting between top campaign aides and a Kremlin-connected lawyer was designed to “get information on an opponent” — the starkest acknowledgment yet that a statement he dictated last year about the encounter was misleading.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: ‘Too Little Too Late’: Bankruptcy Booms Among Older Americans
articles.snippet: The rate of those 65 and older filing for bankruptcy is three times what it was in 1991, a new study finds, as more enter their later years in a precarious position.
articles.abstract: The rate of those 65 and older filing for bankruptcy is three times what it was in 1991, a new study finds, as more enter their later years in a precarious position.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a rapidly growing share of older Americans, traditional ideas about life in retirement are being upended by a dismal reality: bankruptcy.

articles.headline: Cities’ Offers for Amazon Base Are Secrets Even to Many City Leaders
articles.snippet: As Amazon continues its search for its second headquarters, some city officials wonder what was offered and how much it will cost taxpayers.
articles.abstract: As Amazon continues its search for its second headquarters, some city officials wonder what was offered and how much it will cost taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jared Evans, a member of the Indianapolis City-County Council, is proud that the city is among 20 finalists for one of the most coveted prizes in the country: the planned second headquarters of Amazon.

articles.headline: When a Local Paper Gets New Owners, Partisan Strife Hits Its Doorstep
articles.snippet: Some residents north of Los Angeles are worried about The Santa Clarita Valley Signal’s priorities after comments and tweets by the Republican couple who bought it.
articles.abstract: Some residents north of Los Angeles are worried about The Santa Clarita Valley Signal’s priorities after comments and tweets by the Republican couple who bought it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Santa Clarita Valley Signal is typical of many small-town newspapers across the United States, filled with articles about water use, traffic accidents and missing dogs.

articles.headline: Disney’s Streaming Service Starts to Come Into Focus
articles.snippet: Ricky Strauss, a successful marketer, has been given oversight of original films and TV shows for Disney’s coming streaming service. Does he have what it takes?
articles.abstract: Ricky Strauss, a successful marketer, has been given oversight of original films and TV shows for Disney’s coming streaming service. Does he have what it takes?
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Very little is known about Disneyflix, as some people in Hollywood are calling the Netflix-style streaming service that Disney plans to introduce late next year.

articles.headline: ‘The Beginning of a Wave’: A.I. Tiptoes Into the Workplace
articles.snippet: Artificial intelligence software is making its presence felt in subtle ways, in an unglamorous place: the back office.
articles.abstract: Artificial intelligence software is making its presence felt in subtle ways, in an unglamorous place: the back office.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of predictions about how artificial intelligence is going to reshape where, how and if people work in the future.

articles.headline: Steel Giants With Ties to Trump Officials Block Tariff Relief for Hundreds of Firms
articles.snippet: Nucor and United States Steel have exercised veto power, so far without fail, over other companies, forcing them to buy their products instead of steel from abroad.
articles.abstract: Nucor and United States Steel have exercised veto power, so far without fail, over other companies, forcing them to buy their products instead of steel from abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of America’s biggest steel manufacturers — both with deep ties to administration officials — have successfully objected to hundreds of requests by American companies that buy foreign steel to exempt themselves from President Trump’s stiff metal tariffs. They have argued that the imported products are readily available from American steel manufacturers.

articles.headline: 2 Blasts, a Stampede and a ‘Flying Thing’: Witnesses Tell of Attack on Maduro
articles.snippet: A drone attack that failed to kill President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela unfolded on live TV and in front of many witnesses: “It was like, bang, I had never heard a sound like that in my life.”
articles.abstract: A drone attack that failed to kill President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela unfolded on live TV and in front of many witnesses: “It was like, bang, I had never heard a sound like that in my life.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the presidential box stood the small cadre who run the country: a loyal general who was now the interior minister, the chief judge of the Supreme Court and Nicolás Maduro, the president, who looked down at a parade of national guard troops.
articles.byline: By Ana Vanessa Herrero and Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: In Ohio Election, Republicans Test a Midterm Rescue Plan: Polarization
articles.snippet: An Ohio congressional special election has revealed the strategy Republicans will use to keep power in the House — or to ensure that Democrats win only a small majority.
articles.abstract: An Ohio congressional special election has revealed the strategy Republicans will use to keep power in the House — or to ensure that Democrats win only a small majority.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — Republicans everywhere are confronting an ominous political environment, a Democratic opposition rippling with energy and a president on their own side who is prone to divisive outbursts and policy decrees.

articles.headline: Indra Nooyi, PepsiCo C.E.O. Who Pushed for Healthier Products, to Step Down
articles.snippet: Over 12 years in charge, Ms. Nooyi worked to diversify the company’s products away from decreasingly profitable sugary soft drinks.
articles.abstract: Over 12 years in charge, Ms. Nooyi worked to diversify the company’s products away from decreasingly profitable sugary soft drinks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In her 12 years as chief executive of PepsiCo, Indra K. Nooyi has been part of an elite club: She is one of only a small number of women leading large corporations. It is a position that has often meant her every move received greater scrutiny than the actions of her male peers.

articles.headline: U.S. to Restore Sanctions on Iran, Deepening Divide With Europe
articles.snippet: The Trump administration is betting that the sanctions, which had been lifted under the 2015 nuclear accord that the president abandoned, will force Iran to curb its weapons program.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration is betting that the sanctions, which had been lifted under the 2015 nuclear accord that the president abandoned, will force Iran to curb its weapons program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States said Monday it was reimposing economic sanctions against Iran that were lifted under a 2015 nuclear accord, ratcheting up pressure on Tehran but also worsening relations with European allies.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Alex Jones and Infowars Content Is Removed From Apple, Facebook and YouTube
articles.snippet: Technology firms move to curb one of the loudest voices in conspiracy theories, fueling further debate over free speech online.
articles.abstract: Technology firms move to curb one of the loudest voices in conspiracy theories, fueling further debate over free speech online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Top technology companies erased most of the posts and videos on their services from Alex Jones, the internet’s notorious conspiracy theorist, thrusting themselves into a fraught debate over their role in regulating what can be said online.
